This security update includes quality improvements that were a part of update  
KB5041582 
 (released August 27, 2024). Below is a summary of the key issues that this update addresses when you install this KB. If there are new features, it lists them as well. The bold text within the brackets indicates the item or area of the change we are documenting. 
[Windows Installer] 
 When it repairs an application, the User Account Control (UAC) does not prompt for your credentials. After you install this update, the UAC will prompt for them. Because of this, you must update your automation scripts. Application owners must add the Shield icon. It indicates that the process requires full administrator access. To turn off the UAC prompt, set the  
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer\DisableLUAInRepair 
 registry value to  
1 
. The changes in this update might affect automatic Windows Installer repairs; see  
Application Resiliency: Unlock the Hidden Features of Windows Installer 
. 
If you installed earlier updates, only the new updates contained in this package will be downloaded and installed on your device. 
For more information about security vulnerabilities, please refer to the new  
Security Update Guide 
 website and the  
September 2024 Security Updates 
. 
Windows 10 servicing stack update (KB5043935) - 19044.4892 and 19045.4892 
This update makes quality improvements to the servicing stack, which is the component that installs Windows updates. Servicing stack updates (SSU) ensure that you have a robust and reliable servicing stack so that your devices can receive and install Microsoft updates. 
Known issues in this update 
Symptom 
Workaround 
After installing this update, you might be unable to  
change your user account profile picture 
. 
When attempting to change a profile picture by selecting the button  
Start 
>  
Settings  
> 
 Account  
> 
 Your info 
 and, under 
 Create your picture 
, clicking on  
Browse for one,  
you might receive an error message with error code 0x80070520. 
We are working on a resolution and will provide an update in an upcoming release. 
After installing this security update, you might face issues with booting Linux if you have enabled the dual-boot setup for Windows and Linux in your device. Resulting from this issue, your device might fail to boot Linux and show the error message “Verifying shim SBAT data failed: Security Policy Violation. Something has gone seriously wrong: SBAT self-check failed: Security Policy Violation.” 
The August 2024 Windows security update applies a Secure Boot Advanced Targeting (SBAT) setting to devices that run Windows to block old, vulnerable boot managers. This SBAT update will not be applied to devices where dual booting is detected. On some devices, the dual-boot detection did not detect some customized methods of dual-booting and applied the SBAT value when it should not have been applied. 
Please refer to the workaround mentioned in Windows release health site for this issue.

summary:
KB5043064 is a security update released on September 10, 2024, targeting Windows 10 Enterprise LTSC 2021, Windows 10 IoT Enterprise LTSC 2021, and Windows 10 version 22H2 (OS Builds 19044.4894 and 19045.4894). The update addresses critical vulnerabilities, including those related to User Account Control (UAC) behaviors during application repair processes, which may necessitate automation script updates. For installations, prerequisite updates KB5011543 or KB5003173 must be installed depending on the method of deployment, either for offline servicing or WSUS. Specific configurations and registry modifications for UAC settings are detailed in the update documentation.

**Technical Breakdown**

**Vulnerabilities and Exploits**:
- This update addresses high-impact vulnerabilities involving User Account Control (UAC) not prompting for credentials during application repairs, which impacts automated processes.
  
**Known Issues in This Update**:
- **Profile Picture Error**:
  - Impact: Users are unable to change their profile picture.
  - Workaround: None available; under investigation.
  - Error Code: 
    ```
    [Error Code]
    `0x80070520`
    ```
- **Dual-Boot Linux Boot Issue**:
  - Impact: Devices with dual-boot setups may fail to boot Linux.
  - Error Message: “Verifying shim SBAT data failed: Security Policy Violation.”
  - Workaround: Refer to the Windows release health site for a workaround.

**Installation Process and Prerequisites**:
- To install this update, ensure the following prerequisites are met based on your deployment scenario:
  - **For offline OS image servicing**:
    - If your image does not include KB5011543 or later, install KB5014032 before proceeding.
  - **For WSUS deployment or standalone installations**:
    - Install KB5005260 if your devices will not have KB5003173 or later.
- **Preferred Update Channels**:
  - Windows Update: Automatic updates.
  - Windows Update for Business: Automatic installation based on policies.
  - Microsoft Update Catalog: For standalone package retrieval.
  - WSUS: Sync necessary for Windows 10, version 1903 and later security updates.

- **Uninstallation Instructions**:
  To uninstall the LCU after installing the combined SSU and LCU:
  ```
  [Powershell]
  ```powershell
  DISM /online /get-packages
  DISM /Remove-Package /PackageName:<LCU Package Name>
  ``` 
  Note: Using `wusa.exe` with the `/uninstall` switch will not function due to the combined package structure. 

Ensure that all steps are followed meticulously to maintain compliance and system integrity post-update.
